nodes.bodyText: I think its cleaner to just have an SMR that is a whole which is always undoable. When applyUndoRecordUnsafe is called, it just results in a no-op.
Rather than signaling this condition via an exception, maybe a better approach would be to have a globally unique instance that signals a hole.
We changed to put hole into ResolvedQueue, and return an empty list to be ignored by VLO.
Can you move this to the caller? if its a no-op, then you skip calling applyUpdateUnsafe
Actually, if StreamViewSMRAdapter filter's these holes out then you dont need any changes in the VLO.
previous and current will return an empty list, so need to change that while loop a little bit.
This layer only understands ILogData can you move this conversion to StreamViewSMRAdapter which actually maps ILogData to SMREntry
Can you read back the address and make sure its a hole?
Done.
Yea can get rid of the NOP notion by propagating the holes to the Stream layer but then filtering them out just before consumption in the StreamViewSMRAdapter

@lixinchengdu I think your initial argument that the object layer should always see SMREntry makes more sense. But even on master, it seems like an empty list is returned (look at line 100).
I think returning an empty list is error-prone can hide issues, maybe we should explicitly fail if the entry is not ISMRConsumable or a DataType.DATA

Sorry for going back and forth on this, but can we reintroduce the NO-OP SMR ? I think its better to be more concise and handle holes explicitly in the object layer instead of just using an empty list as a signal.
If the SMREntry is a no-op we can skip calling applyUndo, likewise we can skip the apply on stream forward?
By the way this will break existing consumers of IStreamView (i.e. transaction pollers), because now see unexpected holes.
They should not IMO. What entries are seen by the client is dictated by getNextEntries() and that function filters out the holes.

Just making sure my reasoning is correct. If the current entry is a hole, the entries list is going to be empty, making entries.stream().allMatch(SMREntry::isUndoable) evaluate to true.
Also, since the list is empty, it.hasPrevious() will always be false.
Yes, hole entry will skip this if block.
You can make this a bit cleaner by calling data.isData() and data.isHole().
Done.
Same comment applies here.
Can you please add a note that this getter is for testing purposes or perhaps the annotation VisibleForTesting
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -84,6 +84,7 @@
     /**
      * The stream view this object is backed by.
      */
+    @Getter

nodes.bodyText: Sure, I will add a VisibleForTesting function.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -84,6 +84,7 @@
     /**
      * The stream view this object is backed by.
      */
+    @Getter

nodes.bodyText: I am a bit confused, why do we want to surface the hole itself to the object layer? wouldn't that give the wrong behavior? If we are enforcing holes for different reasons (materialize a stream or any other reason), a client should not perceive it...If we are directly consuming the stream it would perceive them right?
Do you mean we should add hole to ResolvedQueue in AbstractQueuedStreamView?

We are adding it here, right? Which I believe is correct... My question is more like, when it's a hole readNext is being set to false meaning that the upper layer receives this hole. So if you are directly manipulating a stream a nextUpTo would return a hole at some point, or is it further filtered? Maybe I did not see when we filter it in upper layers

Discussed offline, skip hole in nextUpTo to update pointer.
Added comment why we add hole and skip it, also added this unit test to StreamViewTest.

Resursive call is not good practice in production, it could blow up stack. I know you are referencing from the recursive code right below, but that is basically dead code.
Also, why don't we do this in removeFromQueue?  We can read the next one if current is a hole in removeFromQueue right? That seems cleaner.

Yes, I agree that recursive call is not good.
If we have a hole in streamA's tail, we read this hole can continue to read the next one in removeFromQueue, and return null. Then it won't call updatePointer(entry), so pointer is still behind this hole and we do not improve performance.

This the problem of existing code organization, we need to clean it up later.
Though I think this does not matter in your case, as long as you put the hole into the resolvedQueue via addToResolvedQueue, the maxResolution will be updated: https://github.com/CorfuDB/CorfuDB/blob/master/runtime/src/main/java/org/corfudb/runtime/view/stream/AbstractQueuedStreamView.java#L87
then next time maxResolution will prevent extra sequencer call. But using globalPointer instead of maxResolution can prevent unnecessary TrimmedException, so it's ok for now. I think later on we should reorg this part of code.

I feel this might not be completely correct in case of sequencer regress.  I think we need to check containsStream() even for a hole, as a hole could be a real hole, which has no stream info, or a no-op which still belongs to some stream. Consider this case:

In epoch 0, sequencer issues a token with address 100 to stream A.
No one writes to this token, but the client queries sequencer for stream A and get back a bitmap that 100 belongs to stream A.
Epoch changes to 1, new sequencer boots up, recovers the stream tail map from log unit, since no one writes to that token with address 100, log unit does not know about that token, neither does new sequencer.
New sequencer issues token 100 to stream B to new client
New client uses this token to enforce a hole for stream B (the checkpoint hole).
Now the old client which operates on stream A finish the read, but it reads a hole with backpointer of stream B, since it's a hole, you will update the stream A's pointer to point to 100, which belongs to stream B and also put it in to the resolved queue.

So in this case we end up pointing stream A's pointer to a hole that belongs to stream B and put it into A's resolved queue.
Yes, I added check containsStream() for a no-op hole
Same here, we might end up pointing to an address belonging to a different stream.
Done.

Sorry please ignore the previous commnet, I forgot we also need to include a real hole.
I think we need to add a special NO_OP type, it's much cleaner in logic, and could solve the recursive call issue (nextUpTo does not need to retry for a NO_OP entry, just return to upper layer), if you would like to do...
NO_OP type is cleaner in logic, but it involves more code reorg... I think we can combine it with further cleanup.
I think we probably don't need to check containsStream here because when we call this method, logdata that does not belong to this stream should already be filtered out, could you double check?
yes, removed.
